1451221112.title: Where does the Story come from?

145122112.content: Considering the nature of this storyline will Sakura dream it?
145122112.title: How will this Happen?

1451221121.content:
Sakura lay down as Kero turned out the light. It was Friday night and she didn't have to attend school in the morning so she had the option of a lie-in. As she lay in bed she struggled to doze off as she had actually been studying hard. Her literature teacher had assigned her class a book review with a limited selection and, what was more, she divided the class into study pairs. The good news was that Sakura and Tomoyo had been assigned to the same book; the bad news was they only had two choices left, both originating in the British Isles: Lord of the Rings or Gulliver's Travels. Tomoyo alone could've tackled either but, after a brief discussion, they settled on Gulliver's Travels as it seemed lighter than Lord of the Rings.

The day that had just gone saw Sakura doing what studying she could. She was quite surprised to find herself becoming engrossed in the book. It was fortunate that Tomoyo and her could have a copy each and then pool their efforts. In fact she had only just managed to put the book down when she had reached halfway. The rush of detail was now getting to her as she drifted off to sleep.

To sleep perchance to dream...
1451221121.title: Don't Read Too Much Before Bed

choices: With the Help of the Waves
14512211211.content:
Sakura lay upon the deck of the ship. Wondering what she was doing here she suddenly remembered that she was supposed to be whale watching for her class assignment. Getting up off the deckchair, not sure why or how she was on it in the first place. She went to the bow and looked out across the ocean. Then she noticed that it was a sailing ship in spite of its size. However she wasn't surprised to find that she was wearing summerwear.

"You had better get below deck, little miss." Said a voice. Turning round Sakura saw the stern but kindly face of a familiar old man dressed in a uniform. "The sea's not looking too friendly today." He pointed off to the side where black clouds were looming. Sakura couldn't remember how sailboats could sail adjacent to the wind but she was sure this man knew what he was talking about.

"Yes!" She responded as she headed for the nearest hatchway.

At first Sakura felt nervous during the storm but confident as the ship rocked wildly, the water splashed against the porthole and the thunder clapped. She lay upon the bunk waiting for the storm to pass and making sure she wouldn't get susceptible to seasickness. But things went from bad to worse. One huge wave rocked her from the bunk and, before long, water began to seep in. She hauled herself out of the room and did what she could to make for a higher deck without going outside. Then everything turned upside down.

The next thing Sakura knew she was on a raft made of broken planks drifting in a calmer sea. She coughed up some seawater, leaving a terrible taste of salt in her mouth. Looking back she was horrified to see the ship she was on in many fragments. Further more, as the clouds drifted away she noticed the sun was setting. However a look in another direction revealed dry land. How does she get there?
14512211211.title: The Dream Begins

145122112112.content:
Though Sakura was a strong swimmer she wasn't sure how far away the land was; sure it couldn't have been much more than three miles but even she couldn't swim three miles non-stop (yet). She thought of paddling but all she had were her own limbs; surely if she tried and rested maybe the currents would make it worse. She decided to wait and see what would happen.

After a brief prayer Sakura found that the land did indeed look closer, by now the sun had just dipped below the horizon. She made a mental note to make an offering to the gods of the sea.

When it became difficult to see colour in the low light Sakura felt sure that she was now close enough to swim. She slipped off the raft and swam with all her might to the shore. Of course this did tire her out fairly soon but she now felt something against her knee. Worried that she may have had a run in with a dangerous marine animal she took one deep breath and stuck her head under the water. After a few seconds she brought it back up, feeling better knowing that her knee had made contact with sand. She now waded the rest of the way.

Upon reaching the beach Sakura checked the condition of the sand. The first thing she noticed told her that it must be high tide, the second thing was how especially fine the sand appeared to be. She was weary now, she had been swimming flat out and the earlier struggle to escape a sinking vessel meant that she had used the same amount of energy in one hour that she usually used in four. She took a few more steps before finally deciding to lie down and rest. What is she going to sleep upon?
145122112112.title: Arrival in Lilliput

1451221121122.content:
Sakura lay down upon some grass that was astonishingly short for its location. She could hardly keep her eyes open as she lay looking out to sea, where the shipwreck was now just some minute silhouettes in the darkness.

"Where am I anyway?" She murmured as her eyelids slowly fell. Not long afterwards she turned onto her back and let her hands rest at the side.

Shall we go straight to see what Sakura will wake up to or shall we find who will first encounter her?
1451221121122.title: Grass

choices: Water drips on one of them
14512211211222.content:
Rika, Naoko and Chiharu were out on the beach early in the morning. Their week was divided according to family necessity and imperial obligations. Today was a Saturday and they were beachcombing, hoping for things that could either be of use to or enrich their families and villages.

"Found anything, Naoko-chan?" Rika called out to the bespectacled girl who was trying the water's edge.

"Just the usual," She replied picking up things Rika couldn't see given the distance, "Limpets and periwinkles." Rika nodded. It was good for the village to make use of whatever food washed up at shore; much more interesting than government rations. It wasn't illegal either, the anti-scavenging law was abolished several years ago not long after the current emperor's coronation.

"Chiharu-chan?" Rika checked at the landward end of the beach. A girl with pigtails scanned the sand, sometimes scraped it away from a possibility, and usually dismissed it.

"Just an old boot." She answered. Rika sighed at this. Boots were good as a source of leather but didn't have much purpose in their village. Looking up the beach Rika's eyes bogged out; the other two were focusing too much on the small things in the sand but she saw something that would be of great value. "So that's what his majesty meant when he said 'You can't see the woods for the trees'." The others looked at her bewildered and then, following her gaze, gasped upon the sight of a great object made of glass and metal. They all ran towards it.

"Amazing!" Naoko commented as she put her hand upon the glass. "What is it?"

"Why's it got a metal pole in it?" Chiharu added as she peered inside.

"There are letters and numbers in it." Rika mentioned. They paced round it, wondering as to its purpose.

"I think it's from Blefuscu." Chiharu commented. "Perhaps the emperor should be told. They might be running naval experiments."

"I'm wondering if it might be from a Blefuscan household." Rika commented. "That was a terrible storm last night. Maybe some new-fangled washing line."

"Could it be," Naoko wondered, "A sextant of some kind?" Looking at it again Rika and Chiharu realised that N,E,S and W could well be North, East, South and West.
14512211211222.title: Discovery on the Beach

145122112112221.content:
Suddenly Chiharu felt a large drop of water fall on her head.

"Aargh!" She cried. "I'll have to have another shower!" She shook the water off her, sending some spray on to Rika, who got a taste.

"Seawater." She mentioned. Then Naoko looked up to see where it came from as another drop fell, this time behind Chiharu who had stepped out of the way.

"Lord of the Sun!" She gasped, not taking her eyes off the sight. Chiharu and Rika turned and looked, also becoming flabbergasted. On top of the cliff, with a bit of T-shirt sleeve hanging over, was a giantess. A woman who must've been as tall as the imperial palace, but they weren't totally sure as she was lying down.

"S...So that's where the water came from." Chiharu commented through her shock, noticing the dripping T-shirt sleeve.

"But where...?" Naoko stammered. "How...? Who...?"

"Has anyone else seen her?" Rika asked. "If we're the only ones I'd like to try putting off reporting this until we know if she's friendly. If not then we'd best try to report as fast as possible."

"There's no knowing what would happen if we were found to have withheld this from the emperor." Chiharu commented. "Furthermore if she's not friendly we'd be goners for sure." Naoko cringed at the thought.

"I wouldn't like to see someone suffer needlessly," Rika mentioned, "If we told the emperor and she turns out to be bad then we may be shown gratitude for alerting the country, but if they inhibit her even though she might be quite nice I... I don't how I could live with myself." What do they decide?
145122112112221.title: It's a Giantess!

1451221121122212.content:
"I don't like taking chances." Chiharu commented. "The emperor must be told; he's a wise man."

"That is indeed true." Rika responded. "It's his advisors that I'm worried about."

"Well," Said Naoko, "Better safe than sorry. I don't consider it wise for us to remain here defenceless when she wakes." With this they gather what they can and run back home.

When the news reached their village everyone there turned out to see Sakura for themselves. Everyone's reaction varied slightly but awe was always present. With this they then sent a runner to the capital of Lilliput, Mildendo.

Before the Emperor and his entourage arrived Sakura stirred slightly, unnerving the people watching her as one of her hands flopped on to the beach and the shifting dislodged some rocks. Upon the approach they could all see that the rumour was true; the country really had a real live giantess on its shores.

"Goodness gracious." Remarked the emperor as he exited his coach. "This is a turn up for the books." He ascended an improvised podium. He wasn't there for five minutes before a member of his escort whispered in his ear.

"The locals say that she had stirred in her sleep." He whispered. "This caused some rocks to fall on the beach. My lord, it would be prudent to tie her down before she does any more damage." The emperor thought this over and replied.

"Yes, it would be prudent but not too tight. We don't know what her intentions are and I don't want to appear too hostile. We can make sure that she won't move without clear intent and have archers ready in case she is sure of attacking."

"My Lord!" The escort remarked. "Are you sure of this?!? Women are trouble and a giant woman is a catastrophe. We must rope her down firm and bring forth cannons to stop her mischief."

"She is a child." The emperor replied. "We mustn't be too hard on her. Harder than our children, true enough, but her arrival could be a godsend instead of a curse." With that the order was given out that the giantess be roped in such a way that she couldn't move without being spacially aware. The archers were deployed but were not put at the ready so as to avoid any trigger-happy soldiers spoiling the emperor's hopes of diplomacy. What happens when these preparations are over?
1451221121122212.title: News Spreads Fast

choices: Wondered who Could be an Ambassador for Sakura
14512211211222121.content:
Sakura groaned, her eyes opening up as she awoke. The groan unnerved the civilian population around her but the imperial entourage did not cringe. She attempted to move but noticed that her arms and legs couldn't budge.

"What the...?" Then she heard some distant gasps. Followed by faint muttering, which sounded like 'It talks' or 'She talks'. Then she heard a clear voice.

"Pull back! Pull back!" It shouted.

"What's going on?" She asked turning her eyes to the side away from the beach. She saw her answer. She was tied down by strings and was surrounded by people no bigger than her thumb. "Hoe!" This hit hard on those closest to her.

"It's a monster!" Declared the emperor's escort. "We must kill it!"

"Watch your tongue!" The emperor told him. "If you're not careful you'll demand yourself into a noose. I'm sure she wasn't roaring." The escort looked bewildered. "I think she's scared." He smiled.

"Um," Sakura started as she considered what was happening, "I'd like to get up if I may." The emperor almost sniggered at this.

"Fancy that." He remarked. "She's asking us if she can move when she only needs to put some more effort in." As he wondered how to safely permit her to rise someone handed him a megaphone. "You may rise, giant one." He called through the megaphone. "Please be careful of the proximity of my subjects and do not worry about the ropes." Sakura, although confused, took heed in this announcement and carefully lifted one arm, tugging at the ropes until they could no longer take the strain, and then doing the same with her other arm before pushing herself up. When she finished only the ropes on her legs remained. Everyone was agog at seeing this massive girl sit up. The emperor now...
14512211211222121.title: She's Waking Up!

145122112112221212.content:
All the emperor knew about this giant girl was that she could speak the language he knew, she appeared to be very peaceful and civilised and she turned up overnight. He didn't yet know if she had always been the size she was or if she had exponentially grown. Considering the unwitting danger she might pose he figured that she would need a Lilliputian representative, someone who could act as a go-between between the imperial court and the giantess. Then he remembered something.

"Did the messenger say that three young girls found her?" He asked an adjutant, who acknowledged this. "And who are they exactly?"

"Well," His aide replied, "They are the only daughters of the local families Mihara, Yanagisawa and Sasaki." The emperor almost started at this.

"Sasaki?" He checked. "Is that the same Sasaki who works in the kitchens? Pudding chef, knows his cakes, that sort of thing." With this known he now called for the mothers of the three to come forward with their daughters.

"You've done very good, Rika-chan." Rika's mother told her as they made their way through the crowd, expecting a reward.

"This is it!" Chiharu's mother mentioned as they made their way. "You're gonna be somebody." Naoko's mother didn't say anything, being temporarily struck dumb by Sakura's enormity.

Once the formality of greeting was finished the emperor checked their identities and then went on with what he had to say.

"Chiharu Mihara, Rika Sasaki, Naoko Yanagisawa," He announced, "In recognition of your services to the court of Mildendo I hereby proclaim that you take on special roles in the name of Lilliput with regards to this monumentous discovery." He couldn't help himself for he loved a laugh. The mothers were desperately proud, but would they be when they heard exactly what he had in mind?
145122112112221212.title: Candidates

1451221121122212121.content: Who does the Emperor of Lilliput choose to be the emissary for Sakura?
1451221121122212121.title: Choose the Ambassador

14512211211222121211.content:
"Rika Sasaki," The Emperor of Lilliput addressed her, "Your family is already known by the court for your culinary skills, now I hereby proclaim that you shall be given the title and job of Lilliputian emissary to the giantess." Rika gasped as she felt a flood of emotions, her mother seemed to be in a state of ambivelance.

"Your lordship," Her mother mentioned, "Are you serious in this endevour? Does my daughter really have what it takes to be an ambassador?"

"Mrs. Sasaki," He replied, "In the current climate information must flow fast through the land. Your daughter is tactful, caring and mature beyond her age. Furthermore it seems that the giantess is not much older than she is. Rika Sasaki will be a representative between us and her." He emphasised the last 'her' so as to indicate that he meant Sakura.

"Great Emperor," Rika declared, "I shall accept the responsibility of the duty that you have assigned me. I do not intend to let you down." He gave her a reassuring smile.

Looking down upon the crowd around her Sakura wondered what was going on. She was now in a land of little people and, she noticed, everything else was on their scale. Whoever was the ruler of this land had allowed her to sit up and now there was nothing except some distant voices that she could not deduce coherent words from.

Who does the Emperor address now?
14512211211222121211.title: Ambassador Rika

145122112112221212112.content:
"Naoko Yanagisawa," The emperor now addressed, "I have seen your latest school report," She flushed, "Your creativity is a bit on the heavy side, bear this in mind when you wish to write." This was a warning; absolute monarchies aren't known for their freedom of speech. "However your mathematical prowess is second to none. With this in mind I hereby proclaim that you shall be the one who will calculate how we can cater for our visitor. As to a title such has not been done before so I must have time to find a better name for this position." Naoko's eyes sparkled. Now her mother found her voice.

"I can only hope that she will not be getting too close." She said, fearing as to what could happen to Naoko if she was within Sakura's reach.

"She may," The emperor told her, "She may. As things stand I suspect that it will be mostly a desk job." This did not change her concerns but it did encourage her to keep her tongue still.

Now it was Chiharu's turn. She had stood there listening to the roles her friends would have. She was scared for Rika as her role would mean often being in close proximity to Sakura but wondered if she would also have a significant role.

"Chiharu Mihara," He addressed her, "Do you know what role is left for a girl so big as her?" Chiharu thought about this as she wondered what Rika and Naoko couldn't offer.

"I'm only a simple peasant." She replied humbly. "My brain cannot handle the riddles you so skillfully craft." The emperor sighed. Even after seven years there were still crawlers in his realm.

"Don't fool yourself, young one." He responded. "You do actually have a fairly assertive tone. Does that give you a clue?" Chiharu wondered what role being assertive would entail.

"Security." She answered. "This giant girl needs a permament escort to stop her causing damage."

"More important than that." The emperor told her. Chiharu thought again.

"Route planning." She guessed. "If she wants to explore Lilliput her route will have to be thoroughly prepared for."

"Even more important still." He said. Chiharu couldn't deduce what he meant. What is the answer?
145122112112221212112.title: The Remaining Roles

1451221121122212121122.content:
"Logistics?" Chiharu double-checked.

"My Chiharu's going to be a delivery girl?" Her mother inquired.

"Not just a delivery girl," The emperor answered, "She'll be the Giant's Quatermaster."

"Which means..." Chiharu mused.

"You will be in charge of deciding how, who, when and what will be delivered." He finished.

"My lord," Chiharu's mother addressed him, "My family have agreed with the Yamazakis that Chiharu shall marry their second youngest son. I'm not sure what impact this will have on the arrangement."

"Mrs. Mihara," He replied, "Though arranged marriages are not illegal I do not consider them wise. If she loves him and he loves her then I do not see that it will be of much consequence." Chiharu's mother still looked concerned; she loved her daughter true enough and the chance that she'd lose her was making her uneasy, but the thought that the contract between the two families could not be fulfilled made even worse. What happens next?
1451221121122212121122.title: Quatermaster Chiharu

choices: The Emperor finds a Good Argument
14512211211222121211221.content:
Chiharu now found herself being held tight by her mother, her view of the emperor being obstructed by her body.

"I don't want my daughter abandoning her family!" She declared, her eyes filled with worry and desperation. The emperor sighed; he could warrant that Mrs Mihara be held back while Chiharu took on her new role but he didn't like using this technique, preferring diplomacy and tactics.

Up above Sakura had her eyes firmly set upon the crowd around the Emperor of Lilliput, wondering what all the hubbub was. It was becoming difficult for her to maintain the same position so her hands were regularly changing position, causing unease amongst the people nearby.

Chiharu's mother was steadfast. Around her imperial guards were ready to forcibly separate her and Chiharu upon the emperor's instruction. The emperor himself was trying his best to negociate with her in spite of an advisor encouraging the traditional model of enforcement. How is the situation resolved?
14512211211222121211221.title: A Firm Stand

145122112112221212112212.content:
"Mum," Chiharu mentioned as she pulled her face out of her chest, "Don't endanger yourself. I do love Young Yamazaki and I did think that I'd marry him but the nation comes first. There is a chance we may not marry but the chance is small. You cannot argue about a private family arrangement when the needs of the country are on the cards. The needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few or the one." Those within earshot were impressed, though they did feel deja vu at hearing this.

"Okay," Her mother sighed and relaxed, "Please try to stay in touch." With that she released her protective hug and stood to the side.

"Congratulations!" The emperor declared when Chiharu had finished. "Such skill in our mother tongue is why I chose you to be the quartermaster. Now let us see how we can accommodate our rather tall visitor for the time being." His understating earned a few sniggers. "First we must set out a restricted area around her. Naoko Yanagisawa how wide must it be for her to be more comfortable?" Naoko now attempted to do some number crunching.

'I'm four foot three,' She thought, 'And my home had a radius of fifteen feet. So, if She's two hundred feet tall...' She struggled at this point, knowing that Sakura wasn't a hundred times bigger than her but that she must've been over one hundred feet high. "May I have an abacus and a piece of paper?" Her request was quickly delivered, all the while Sakura struggled with the long period she was sitting up with her legs jutting ahead of her. 'The difference is, say, forty-seven', Naoko continued to muse, 'So the area would need to be...' She finally gave an answer. "I'd recommend a radius of half a mile from where She is now, just to be on the safe side." She had considered one mile but then her home village would be within that area; in fact it would still be just outside of this range but she wanted Sakura to feel that the people of Lilliput were considerate.

"Very well." The emperor responded. "Let the armed forces know that, from the spot where She sits, at a half-mile radius there shall be..."
145122112112221212112212.title: Time to Plan the GTS Zone

choices: The Emperor makes a Formal Greeting
1451221121122212121122121.content:
"...a barricade with checkpoints where roads cross it. Access shall be restricted to members of the court, those assigned to the area and the giantess herself." He knew that Sakura could easily step over even the best barricades they could set up, he had only said this to reassure the populace. "Further preparations shall be planned for." With this he now instructed that those who were not in the forces, members of the court or persons specifically assigned to tasks within the planned area, to disperse.

Sakura could hear these instructions as they were announced to all. She had mixed feelings as she didn't want to become a need-to-know only individual but she recognised the problems she could hold if anybody were to wander around where she was permitted to. She watched on as a great number of civilians dispersed, with those from the nearest coastal village taking the longest as they said farewell to Rika, Naoko and Chiharu. Finally all that was left was the Emperor of Lilliput, his entourage, a division of archers and the three young girls who had first found her.

"You may shift at your leisure, giant one." The emperor announced through the megaphone. "But please don't stroll." Satisfied with this Sakura reached over with one hand and plucked the ropes from her legs five, six or seven at a time. All around her were awed by the ease with which she did this. With great care Sakura swung her legs round and tucked them away. "Okay," The emperor began, "Let's get those barricades started, shall we?" With this a few officers went forth to acquire the manpower necessary to set the barricades up and also to check exactly where they would go. All that was left was the emperor, a portion of his escort and the three girls. Sakura kept her eyes upon them, awaiting any instructions or questions that these tiny people might have for her.

What happens next?
1451221121122212121122121.title: Move Along

choices: Naoko shall go with them, Rika is to keep Sakura company.
14512211211222121211221212.content:
All of a sudden there was a weird groaning sound, causing several Lilliputians to look around but some, including the emperor, had correctly identified that the sound was coming from Sakura.

"Sorry about that." Said Sakura. "I guess it's been a while since I last had anything to eat." This comment was taken incorrectly by several who cringed and backed away.

"I guess we'd better get her some breakfast." The emperor mentioned. "Miss Yanagisawa, how much do you think she'll need?" Naoko once again turned to the paper and abacus.

'Let's see,' She pondered, 'If an ordinary girl has porridge composed of five fluid ounces of milk and five fluid ounces of oats with a tablespoon of honey, we'll have to get Her...' She fussed over the sums. "One-quarter multiplied by 47 cubed." She muttered. "I do not wish to bear bad news, sire," She spoke up upon making a final decision, "But my calculations indicate that, if she has the same kind of breakfast that we do, we'll need one thousand gallons of milk and a similar volume of oats. Furthermore the usual volume of honey on her scale would be sixty gallons!" The emperor did look a bit concerned.

"Let us try to adapt then." He replied. "If instead of a half-pint of porridge and a tablespoon of honey we instead go for mixed cereals and some meats." Naoko now attempted to number crunch how much of a more plentiful food source would be needed.

"I would reckon," She answered, "We would need ten tons of cereals and enough meat as can be found on six cows. However everyone has a different sized appetite so I fear I may have miscalculated."

"Were that were so," The emperor responded, "Only the one who has to eat will know when she is really full. Miss Mihara!" He called out. "We must ride across the country and access whatever surplus food and drink there is. If all goes well there'll be enough to sustain our visitor for the coming month." While he prepared to leave with Chiharu in tow so that she could fullfill her role of quartermaster what does he wish the other two to do?
14512211211222121211221212.title: What to do for Breakfast?

145122112112221212112212121.content:
"Miss Yanagisawa," The emperor addressed her, "You shall accompany us to ensure that the supplies are at least adequete and also perhaps we can try and formulate other plans to help our guest feel more human." Acknowledging this Naoko followed Chiharu to the royal coach, carrying assorted gear for mathematical use, while Rika stood there thinking over the fact that she'll be the only one left.

"My lord," She inquired, "I have a good idea as to what I must do but where do I start?" The emperor gave her a reassuring smile before answering.

"Just try to talk to her as you would to an ordinary visitor from overseas." This wasn't too much help as the only overseas contact Lilliput had was Blefuscu and it had been far too long for an ordinary girl to know how to talk to a visitor from there. Rika knew that the emperor had a bizarre but harmless sense of humour and a tendancy to talk in riddles, so she was sure that there was an underlying meaning. Watching the door to the coach close she kept wondering what that meaning is.

Up above Sakura observed the organised withdrawal into the coach, wondering what the purpose behind this was. Did they think she'd make them breakfast? Were they intending to use her as a form of execution? She shuddered at the ideas. 'I hope they're just going to try and find some normal food for me?' She thought.

Rika and Sakura watched the coach trundle away, each with different thoughts on their minds. Sakura wondering what their ideas were about getting her some breakfast and Rika wondering how to start forming diplomatic relationships with Sakura. Who makes the first noticable reaction?
145122112112221212112212121.title: What's Occuring?

1451221121122212121122121212.content:
Turning away from the track that the coach had gone down, Rika now focused her attention on the now wide awake and hungry Sakura. She definitely felt nervous as she was totally aware of Sakura's scale, most significantly the size of her mouth and stomach. Rika swallowed as she attempted to relieve the tension.

'I've felt vulnerable before,' She thought, 'But never like this.' She decided to avoid looking at Sakura's lips and instead pay more attention to the limbs. She took note of just how long Sakura's fingers were as they rested on the ground. 'Well,' She thought, 'If she did want a person for breakfast she would probably have eaten me already.' With this unusual reassurance in mind she took a step closer to Sakura. It took thirty seconds for her to summon enough will power to take another, and the same delay occured with every step she made towards Sakura.

Sakura now found that there was only one person left nearby. Even from her high altitude she could tell it was a girl about the same age as her, with a familiar looking hairstyle and her eyes cast down. Sakura kept watch on the tiny girl as she slowly walked towards her, every step barely a quarter of an inch if that.

Rika could feel Sakura's gaze upon her and, for now, it had the effect of weighing her down. Even so she could tell that it wasn't like a predator watching its prey but more of a parent looking on as a child played an unfamiliar game. She was about to take her twelfth step when she caught sight of Sakura's hand rising; she instinctively flinched and crouched down, expecting the worst.

In fact Sakura just held out her hand to the diminuitive figure crouching in the windswept grass, her middle finger being close enough for Rika to touch.

"Don't worry," Sakura told her, "I won't harm you." The tone of her voice was enough for Rika to overcome most of her fear and to slowly look up. She followed the lines on Sakura's hand up to the wrist and then let her eyes roll along the arm up to the shoulder and then finally make eye contact with her.
1451221121122212121122121212.title: Making Contact

14512211211222121211221212121.content:
Gingerly Rika leaned forward and pushed her arms onto Sakura's middle finger before letting her feet leave the ground. Not sure whether she'd be able to walk on a hand she crawled forward into Sakura's palm, using the index and ring fingers as supports. Upon reaching the palm Rika now felt herself being pushed into the flesh as Sakura lifted her into the air. Finally the ascent stopped at Sakura's eye level and Rika got up off her front and rolled around into a comfortable sitting position.

"I'm sorry if I startled you," Sakura mentioned, "But I thought it would be easier if you were closer to my ears." Rika relaxed. She appreciated Sakura's concern and humanitarianism, furthermore she now found it slightly amusing that every one of Sakura's digits was longer than she was tall.

"I'm the one who should be sorry." Rika returned. "I thought you might..." She couldn't finish but Sakura understood.

"Water under the bridge." She commented in an effort to save Rika much embarrassment. "So, what's your name?"

"R...Rika." She replied, stuttering from relief now. "Rika Sasaki." Sakura thought it rather a coincidence that she looked familiar and had a familiar name. "And your name is...?"

"Sakura." She answered. "Sakura Kinomoto." There was now an awkward pause. Who is going to ask the next question
14512211211222121211221212121.title: Getting to Know You

145122112112221212112212121212.content:
"So," Rika spoke up after the silence, "Why are you so big?"

"Well," Sakura responded, "I might as well ask why you're so small." Rika now looked up into Sakura's great emerald orbs with a new sense of wonder.

"Does this mean?" Rika asked; Sakura nodded.

"Where I'm from everything is to me what everything here is to you. Well, nearly everything." Rika couldn't help but giggle at that.

"Amazing!" She gasped. "You're from a land of giants!" Sakura gave an uncertain nod as she sweatdropped.

"And this is a land of tinies." Sakura added.

"So," Rika now inquired...
145122112112221212112212121212.title: A Theory of Relativity

1451221121122212121122121212121.content:
There was a change in Sakura's expression, which was much too hard to hide from Rika due to the size difference and her close proximity. Rika knew that the answer wouldn't be rosy.

"I was shipwrecked." Sakura stated, taking three seconds to say each syllable. "I was on a ship whale-watching when a storm came up tossing everything this way and that and the next thing I knew I was on a piece of wood floating in the sea." Rika turned to the direction of the sea in the hope of finding the raft or the wreck. "I think the currents carried all the debris away from here; if I hadn't spotted this coast I could've been adrift for days." Rika turned back to her.

"So," She deduced, "You decided to come ashore here and sleep on top of a cliff."

"Well," Sakura replied with a nervous smile, "It didn't look like a cliff to me." Rika looked again at the height of the cliff compared to Sakura's towering form.

"No, I guess not." Rika felt much better knowing that the two of them could freely make quips at one another's stature.

"How long was I asleep?" Sakura asked. Rika shrugged and answered.

"I don't really know. My friends and I were combing the beach below the cliffs about an hour or so after sunrise when we discovered your prone form looming over the seaside. It must've been another two hours before you woke up... at least!" Sakura let this sink in before remarking.

"Last thing I remember from last night was lying down here just as twilight was fading out." Rika thought hard about this. If she slept that long it would've been about two hours longer than normal but this was a giantess she was talking to.

"Do giants usually sleep for twelve hours?" She asked. Sakura felt very ambivalent about being called a giant but simply responded.

"Not really. I was just so tired after the whole ordeal, but when left to myself I normally sleep for nine hours." Rika accepted this information reasonably well until she figured that if Sakura could pull several lengths of rope with the pegs out of the ground at once with just one hand it must've been impossible for a Lilliputian to have covered the same distance.

The questions continue. Who asks the next one?
1451221121122212121122121212121.title: The Ordeal at Sea (Recounted)

14512211211222121211221212121212.content:
"So, uh..." Rika carried on once she found out how to stand up in Sakura's hand, "If you don't mind me asking, how tall would you say you are?" Sakura blushed slightly once Rika had finished her question; she was rather embarrassed by her apparent stature in this land.

"Well," She replied, "When I was last measured it read four-foot-three." Rika now stared up into Sakura's eyes, her surprise completely laid bare.

"But," Rika remarked, "I'm four-foot even." Now Sakura stared at the girl she held in her palm.

"What would you call an inch?" Sakura asked. Rika responded by measuring her thumb with the thumb and forefinger of her free hand and, after cutting the space between them in half, held it up to Sakura.

"I'm not sure if you can see it." She commented.

"I can," Sakura answered, "But only just." Now Sakura held her finger and thumb apart with her free hand and got them as close as she could to an inch and presented the measurement to Rika. "This is the inch I know." Rika looked up at Sakura's giant digits hovering in the air.

"Is that," She asked, "Half the length of your thumb?" Sakura nodded but in a slightly uneasy way, denoting that measurements without proper materials wouldn't be accurate. She watched as Rika stumbled across her hand towards her thumb, clearly wishing to compare her height. "Your thumb is more than twice my height." Rika stated. "So, by your standards, I'm less than one inch tall!" Sakura felt pitiful now, as she empathised Rika's sudden sense of inadequacy.

"But only just." She tried to reassure her. "You must be more than three-quarters of an inch." She gingerly shifted her thumb to more easily compare its length to Rika. "See, the distance to my knuckle from your head is barely more than the thickness of my nail." How does Rika respond?
14512211211222121211221212121212.title: A Personal Question

145122112112221212112212121212121.content:
"I appreciate what you're trying to do," Rika remarked, "And it's very kind of you to show a bug-girl respect but I must accept that my potential is negligible compared to yours."

"There's no need to be hard on yourself." Sakura insisted. "After all there are many others around here who'd no doubt feel the same if they were in your shoes. Besides, you still have your intelligence and feelings that do not depend on your size." Rika sat back down on Sakura's Venus mount, still feeling the humility of the situation but slightly cheered by Sakura's consideration. "So, how tall would you say I am?" This question was asked uneasily because, while Rika's height in Sakura's scale made her feel pathetic and helpless, she suspected that her height in Rika's scale would be very embarrassing.

"Well," Rika replied as she looked up at Sakura's face, "One of my friends estimated you to be two-hundred feet high." Sakura thought for a moment.

"Two... hundred?!?" She repeated, thinking aloud as she tried to get a true sense of scale. "A house is typically thirty feet, a school is usually eighty feet or so, trees don't normally grow taller than a hundred and eighty feet." The colour seemed to drain from her face.

"Kinomoto-sama," Rika asked as she couldn't help but address a giantess using a significant title, "Why do you have to feel ashamed when you are so superior to anyone else?"

"It's so embarrassing!" Sakura answered. "I've normally been called cute, little, dear, words that relate to a small build. Sometimes my brother would call me a monster and now, that's what I am." Her eyes were filled with shame.
145122112112221212112212121212121.title: Back at Yer!

choices: Rika asks Sakura some more about her homeland.
1451221121122212121122121212121211.content:
"Please don't belittle yourself, Kinomoto-sama." Rika pleaded. "You're no monster, just a very tall girl. And I must admit you really are quite charming. You must take very good care of your complexion." Sakura looked at her passenger in amazement.

"Y...You really think so?" She asked, resulting in a vigorous nod from the Lilliputian girl. "Ano, could you please drop the 'sama'? I don't want to be thought of as superior just because I'm so much taller than anyone else here." Rika beamed with surprise and joy.

"I don't suppose I could call you 'Sakura' in informal situations?" She checked, resulting in an enormous digit from Sakura's free hand come down and gently tap her on the shoulder.

"As long as I can call you 'Rika-chan'." There was a teasing tone to the giantess's voice. Rika giggled in response to the giant fingertip brushing against her.

"Okay then, Sakura-san." Sakura lifted the finger away from her new friend and asked.

"So, what's going on with all the others?" Rika paused and shifted a bit to look out over the landscape before answering.

"Oh, they've just gone to find you some breakfast. We're not that well-prepared for giant guests." Sakura gave a sigh of relief. "I must admit you've got a wonderful view from up here." Sakura giggled at this.

"Thanks. I find it can get a bit boring after a while when there are no hills to hike or anything like that. Ano, you're okay with heights, I hope." Rika spared a glance through one of the gaps between Sakura's fingers before replying.

"Oh, sure. As long as you don't level out all your digits, I feel safe in your grasp." Rika playfully pushed on Sakura's index finger.
1451221121122212121122121212121211.title: Rika Attempts to Comfort her

choices: Sakura talks some more about Japan.
Rika chats some more about Lilliput.
14512211211222121211221212121212112.content:
"So, what is this land of little people, then?" Sakura asked. Rika smiled at this, knowing that the giantess was only teasing, and answered.

"You have landed in the 'Noble Kingdom of Lilliput', but we usually just call it the Kingdom of Lilliput or just plain Lilliput." Sakura nodded slowly, accepting this information.

"And who rules Lilliput?" She continued to inquire. Rika shook her head as if to say 'that's easy'.

"His Imperial Majesty, the Emperor Eriol." She replied. "What about the land of giants that you come from?" Rika elbowed Sakura's thumb, happy that they could now interact with each other so casually even though Sakura could dispose of her anytime she chose.

"Oh, my home country's called Japan, also known as 'The Land of the Rising Sun'." Sakura replied with a grin of embarrassment. "When I left the ruler was Emperor Akihito, but he doesn't actually have any real official power, the real authority sits with the Diet, members of which are elected by every Japanese adult." This wasn't completely accurate but it provided a fairly satisfactory explanation. Rika was most intrigued and settled down in Sakura's palm, ready to hear more about the strange alien land populated by colossal people.
14512211211222121211221212121212112.title: Introducing Different Cultures

choices: Rika continues to explain Lilliputian society to Sakura.
Sakura talks some more about her homeland.
A convoy arrives with Sakura's breakfast.
145122112112221212112212121212121122.content:
"Um," Sakura continued, "Since I'm gonna be here for a while, what else could you tell me about Lilliput?" Rika figured it would take quite a while to explain all she knew about her society and so did all she could to make herself comfortable in Sakura's palm before answering.

"Well, our country covers an area of what we consider to be 265,000 square miles and I'd guess our population's about 16,472,000 or so. There's only one other country we're in contact with and... well..." She tailed off.

"Is something wrong?" Sakura asked with concern, holding Rika even closer to her eyes which meant the Lilliputian lass could not see her nose or mouth. Swallowing nervously Rika continued.

"We're at war." She squeaked out, causing an expression of nervousness and perplexity to pass over Sakura's face.

"Why?" Rika took up a position of embarrassment and scuffed a shoe over one of the creases in Sakura's palm and said.

"Most people say it's because the people of Blefuscu, that's its name, are backwards. Personally I'm starting to think that this war's been going for so long neither side's completely comfortable with making peace without the other's complete surrender." Sakura made a somewhat exasperated groan, which caused Rika to flinch.
145122112112221212112212121212121122.title: There's a War on

choices: A convoy with Sakura's breakfast finally arrives.
Sakura talks about some of the differences between Japan and Lilliput.
Rika carried on talking about Lilliputian society and comparisons with Blefuscu.
1451221121122212121122121212121211221.content:
"What differences could be enough to cause war?!?" Sakura asked, almost toppling Rika over with the power of her voice. Making herself as comfortable as she could Rika mulled over the information she had before answering.

"The Emperor came to power because he was the closest male relative of the previous emperor; in Blefuscu they have a queen instead who came to power by being the closest female relative to her predecessor. In Lilliput we keep to the left side of the road while Blefuscans prefer to keep to the right side. Blefuscans use a decimalised system in almost every form of measurement while Lilliput uses a more varied range of measurements." As Rika considered other differences Sakura couldn't help but interject.

"So Blefuscu uses metric?" She asked; Rika's lack of reply prompted her to build on the term. "So you would be 120cm tall by their measurements." Sakura's eyes blinked in bewilderment over how she was able to find the metric alternative so quickly. Rika gave an affirmative response, impressed by the swiftness with which Sakura worked it out but figured that her giant size meant such mental arithmetic would be so much easier for her. "Then, if I'm 200 feet high by your standards, the Blefuscans must consider me to be... 60 metres tall!" After a few seconds Rika spoke up again.

"They even differ in construction. For many years now Lilliputian architecture prioritises the minimal use of wood in buildings while Blefuscu has retained the old rules of construction involving timber and plaster among other things. And there are cultural issues; in Lilliput the Imperial court determines position by a combination of local elections and physical dexterity." Sakura moved her hand up and slightly away from her face as a fairly clear indication that she wasn't sure what Rika was talking about. "Whenever a vacancy in the Imperial court has to be filled every local authority puts forward a candidate who received the most votes from every adult man who has their own property, these candidates must then go over or under a bar that's varied in height each time and whoever shows the greatest flexibility in achieving this gets the most desired position available and any further vacancies are filled in a top-down manner." Sakura's face filled her view as she watched it shift from a look of confusion to one of realisation. The giant girl beamed as she remarked.

"Oh. Like limbo-dancing." Rika gave a half-shrug as she conceded to Sakura's idea.

"If that's what you call it in Japan."

Tomoyo looked out over the rolling sea from the bow of the hired yacht. The fresh air was brisk and stimulating; she spared a glance back at her mother who was stretched out upon a sun chair.

"Oka-san." She stated. "You almost look like an archipelago lying there." She gave a mild giggle as Sonomi glanced at her over the rim of her sunglasses.

"Tomoyo," She replied, "You shouldn't read those fantasy novels so much." Tomoyo mellowed a little but responded with.

"But don't you think it would be awesome if you could be mistaken for an island chain?" She settled into a dream-like state, picturing how it would be were her mother a giant.

"It isn't proper for a lady to wield such extensive power." Sonomi replied. "Economic success is one thing but for a woman to be physically stronger than a man just isn't done." Tomoyo returned to staring at the sea; moping over this old attitude that still prevailed in the undercurrents of Japanese society.

That evening a storm whipped up, creating great distress for those on board. Despite everything they did Tomoyo and Sonomi were lost overboard. As to the rest of the crew they may have come out of it successfully but then again, maybe not.
14512212121.title: Gulliver or Gilligan?

145122121211.content:
Tomoyo Daidouji came up to the surface, gasping for breath; while she was a capable swimmer she was no medal winner. She was rather distressed to find that the boat was nowhere in sight but the good news was that the sea was getting calmer; taking a series of measured breaths she retained her calm and scouted the area for anything suitably buoyant. Hypothermia was no worry for the water was at a fairly reasonable temperature.

To her relief a life jacket floated into view. It took about ten minutes but she finally had it on and so could focus more of her effort on traversing the waters in search of a vessel or a shoreline, but most of all she was worried as to her mother's well-being.

After a little over half an hour had passed she came upon more good fortune; a rubber raft had floated into her vicinity. Once she was on board she paused and then began to beseech the heavens for the sake of Sonomi.

Should we, the readers and writers, be so concerned about Sonomi?
145122121211.title: Audentes fortuna iuvat, mitis.

Switch to the viewpoint of the locals for now.
1451221212112.content:
Tomoyo had rested and prayed for approximately one hour before she opted to recommence paddling for she knew her window for acquiring the necessities of life was closing every second. She came upon a surprising delight as the full moon shone forth and illuminated a distant coast. With eagerness Tomoyo paddled towards it, a gentle breeze aiding her efforts.

In the space of fifteen minutes Tomoyo eased up on the paddling and looked at the shore. There seemed to be rolling hills rising up on the right while a suggestion of cliffs rested on the left, so her option was to make straight ahead where she could be sure of finding a suitable beach to make landing on.

After another half hour Tomoyo was close enough to see what seemed like woodland or a thicket of bushes screening the beach from further inland. If I can just make the shore I can rest for the night and seek help in the morning, unless help comes to me. It was only ten minutes before Tomoyo found she could vacate the raft and drag it up onto the beach, taking the life jacket off and stowing them up beside the small rise of land separating the beach from the thicket. With the moon having set Tomoyo figured that what she was seeing was an overgrowth of wild shrubs, meaning that access to the beach by land would be from either side.

"Have I reached Guam?" She whispered curiously as she lay down against the rise, her hair resting rather close to the thicket as she began to doze off, hoping her mother would make landfall as well as she did or better.
1451221212112.title: Land Ahoy

She set a bookmark in her copy of Gulliver's Travels, turned off the light and made for her bed. Lying in the dark she smiled as she thought about Sakura, now and again scenes from the book crept in. Eventually she drifted off to sleep.
14512212122.title: And So To Bed

145122121221.content:
Tomoyo found herself lying on a wooden raft out in the ocean under a bright sunny sky. Looking down at herself she identified her white lace dress and her black buckled shoes. Reaching up she felt her head, it was more vague than usual but it seemed that her hair was hanging loose in a cascading wave. Getting to her knees she looked about and espied a coastline stretching across one horizon; there was no doubt that she should head for it, so looked round again and found a plank that could be used as a paddle.

It took some furious paddling but the currents seemed to be in her favour. Tomoyo was not particularly athletic but she kept herself in reasonable shape. She rested for a moment but it was now clear that she was heading for a shingle beach with some light brown cliffs rising above it. While she rested she took the opportunity to check what sort of marine life was in the vicinity. It was something of a surprise to find that the sea was currently clear of plant and animal life visible to the naked eye. Cautiously she dipped her hand into the water and lifted it out in a cupped formation, only to find no evidence of excessive algae or plankton.

Looking up again Tomoyo noticed that she had drifted even closer to the coast than she expected; picking up the paddle again she pushed the raft ever closer, this time keeping a steady pace. Soon the waves took over and pushed the raft onto the shingle, allowing her to hop off. Common sense gave her a clear indication of what to do, she grabbed hold of a piece of rope she didn't remember seeing and pulled the raft further along the shingle. The high tide mark was hard to find so she opted to stick with halfway between the surf and the cliffs as the place to leave it for now. Tomoyo now figured that she should check her pockets; she found her digital video camera, four spare batteries, a lace handkerchief and a handful of sherbet lemons.

So much for being prepared. She sighed. At least I can document this place. Where exactly am I, anyway? She looked round and walked about for a moment, trying to see some significant variation in the cliff-side.
145122121221.title: Sailing to Pastures New

Suddenly the ground began to quake a little. The small tremors steadily grew and loud crashing noises could be heard as if something were slamming the ground. Strangely, as the slamming seemed to get closer and louder so too did the tremors grow until Tomoyo could make out what looked like brown hair in the distance over the cliffs, then as the figure came closer a forehead appeared over the edge.

Finally, moments later, a colossal bare foot slammed onto the shingle in the distance. Tomoyo couldn't believe her eyes; standing above her, so tall that normal trees would barely reach her knees, was someone who appeared to be Sakura, clad in a one-piece pink bathing suit.

The giantess soon noticed Tomoyo. Having witnessed similar events when Sakura used the "Big Card" and heard about "Sakura's Adventure In Wonderland", she wasn't scared as the giantess picked her up.

"Um, would you protest if I took you home with me?" Sakura asked, prompting Tomoyo to lift her arms up in a gesture of delight.

145312211.content:
The residents of the Daidouji mansion were very joyous, experiencing great contentment regardless as to their position. Sonomi, mistress of the household, took her role seriously both at home and at work, ensuring the continuing prosperity of her family through her diligence. Tomoyo, Sonomi's daughter, was everything that humanity wanted to be: selfless, intelligent, dedicated; she would do anything for the ones she loved. The maids were also happy with their roles as they not only treated Sonomi and Tomoyo as superior but acutally believed that they were; and the bodyguards, they had been trained so well that they too accepted Sonomi and Tomoyo as their superiors, taking the maxim dulce et decorum est pro rector mori (Is is sweet and good to die for one's master) right to their hearts. But underneath all of this all the ladies shared a secret within the mansion.

In the earlier days when Sonomi's ownership of the grand house was in its infancy there was a race who lived under her nose, or more specifically, under her feet. Their origins were unknown but a great number of people the size of pennies. Their origins were unknown as, over time, the facts had been distorted into legends and myths because, living unnoticed by the full-size ladies, proper civilisations could not be established lest they be smashed by a passing foot; as such they were living as feuding tribes doing what they could to secure plenty of resources and maintain homes that could be quickly rebuilt in the event of a major attack by that which is alive or that which is of natural phenomena. It continued this way for several years as they looked upon those who lived in the house as gods for reasons that must be as clear as glass.

One day, when Tomoyo was still particularly young, such a tribe had taken a bold move to infiltrate the house to seek out plenty more resources than could be found in the garden. They struggled to manage when under unwitting attack from the 'gods' before, finally, they were discovered and recognised for what they were. Sonomi thus determined to help these tiny people and, all together, the residents of the mansion went forth to gather all the other tribes and unite them. And so it comes to this, the secret race of tiny people residing in the merciful care of the Daidouji mansion residents hidden from the outside world.
145312211.title: The People Under Daidouji

14531221112.content:
When there was no school work to do and Sakura was not around Tomoyo's mind would dwell either on her dear Sakura or it would wander to her little people at home. She loved them almost as much as Sakura and, of course, her mother. In past days she would've talked to them when she was in a bit of trouble for whatever reason and they would, somehow, have folktales relating to the situation from when they were 'wild' as the time of their tribal existence had become known. Tomoyo loved to hear these tales and had even written several of them down, complete with hypotheses as to the truth behind the myth. She always found it flattering when they described her as a goddess but simply wished to be known as being like them, only bigger; she understood why they saw her and all the other residents of her home as gods but wanted to be sure that misunderstandings would not occur.

Occasionally Tomoyo would find her thoughts about the little people mixing with those of Sakura Kinomoto. Sometimes she envisaged Sakura as being to Tomoeda what she herself was to her little'uns, still other times she'd imagine Sakura as one of her little'uns. Because of this she would, now and again, ask some young girls from her charge to try out costumes she delicately sewed to their size as prototypes for Sakura's own costumes.

In the events of the first episode of the anime between leaving school and going out to capture Sakura's first literal flight on tape this is what happened at the Daidouji mansion. How are the little people set up in there anyway?
14531221112.title: Starting at the Beginning

1453122112.content:
A popular market that had popped up in Japan was that of little people. A highly prolific race that was naturally submissive to those who were bigger. However the passage of time caused major overhauls in terms of how they were sold. Come the 1990s only women and girls could interact with them in accordance with a study of business practice and ownership and, furthermore, they would only be sold to those who would have mutual interest, ensuring both parties were as happy as possible. Strangely enough selected representatives from the little people insisted on retaining an owner's right to eat them, believing it to be a sacrifice that would lead them to heaven for sure; however campaigners amongst those who were regular sized managed to pass a legislation that only those who clearly expressed no qualms in such an act of apparent cannibalism would be sold with the owner having the right to. The punishment for consuming a little who did not have 'right to eat' on their sale information was six months community service for those who fell under the juvenile category of the age of criminal liability and, after thorough debate, six months imprisonment for the first offense amongst adults and inclusion to the littles for the second, after a breakthrough in miniaturisation.

Some of those who were small did not seem to care too much who would buy them or how they would be treated. This meant that they could be put into suspended animation and sold a a much lower price than normal; some businesses would make their suspension chambers into such things as jewellery so as to gain a bit more profit and/or make a special offer.

In Tomoeda one business renowned for this, including a licensed miniaturisor, was the Daidouji Toy and L.P. Co. As such pre-adolescent girls were the largest demographic in Tomoeda's customer base for this. However rumours were floating about that the CEO Sonomi Daidouji had her own private collection (which wasn't too far from the truth) including some persons who had been shrunk for wrong-doings that were offically not significant enough to warrent miniaturisation (which was mostly false). Sometimes the young girls of the district would actually talk about being victims of such a conspiracy and contemplate being in one-another's clutches.
1453122112.title: Japanese Tinies

145312212.content:
Sakura and her friends considered it very bizarre when they each received an identical letter from Matsumoto, inviting them to a special unveiling of new merchandise at Twin Bells. It was curious as it said that they could not bring anyone else unless they were both female and could be trusted to keep quiet. Each of them was reacting in slightly different ways.

Naoko was really excited; for her mysteries and the supernatural were subjects for extensive scrutiny and was only too happy to experience a real enigma like this. Chiharu was simply bewildered as she never associated Matsumoto with this level of secrecy; in fact she never knew of anything weird occurring at Twin Bells since the missing panda incident. Rika felt somewhat uneasy, not knowing why Matsumoto wanted to see them specifically or why it had to be so secret, but she maintained her composure and felt that the benefit of the doubt would be the best option.

Sakura and Tomoyo were both feeling dubious about this whole affair. Sakura had a slight suspicion of an ulterior motive but figured she'd attend; after all anything untoward Matsumoto had a chance of doing Sakura had the power of undoing it a million-fold. Tomoyo was feeling ambivelent as to whether or not the invitation would be beneficial to them but, after a quick word with Sakura, decided that she'd go as, if anything went wrong, at least Sakura would be there.
145312212.title: Sakura and a Strange Invitation

choices: They Take a Closer Look at the Contents
1453122121.content:
All five girls stood outside of the Twin Bells shop looking at the notice on the door. 'CLOSED CONDITIONALLY: REDECORATING EXPECTED' it read; Chiharu suggested giving Matsumoto a ring, apologising for being unable to enter, but Sakura stopped them from leaving, feeling that there was more to this than met the eye. With a sense of anticipation she slowly stepped up to the door, raised her fist and knocked.

After about twenty seconds there was the sound of a bolt being shifted and a key turning in the lock, before the door opened and Maki Matsumoto popped her head out.

"Ah, good." She blurted out. "You're all here. Only five?" They all nodded; Sakura had been tempted to bring Kero with her but decided that she'd rather stick to her word rather than pull the wool over Maki's eyes. The door opened further and Maki invited them all in before closing and locking the door behind them. "This is a special offer that, currently, is only available you the five of you. I do not wish it to be made public as there would be both controversy and dangers of abuse from what I have available." This made Rika and Naoko very uneasy.

Maki lead them into the back room, which only Tomoyo had seen before as being nought but a simple kitchen, followed by some kind of living room before Maki stopped at a door, She took another key from her pocket and unlocked it, opening it up to reveal a few stairs leading down into a large area filled with glass boxes, the kind you get in museums, and continued to lead the five girls into this room.

Once they had all decended the stairs Maki turned back and closed the door behind them, but she did not lock it. Each of them observed the contents of the boxes: They could all see miniature buildings in them but thought of them as little more than models. All were confused for different reasons. Naoko was confused and disappointed by the apparent anticlimax. Rika could not fathom why model villages would have to be kept under wraps. Chiharu was slightly annoyed as well as confused, feeling that her time had been wasted. Tomoyo couldn't understand why only they were allowed to see these models. Sakura, on the other hand, was confused by the conflict of senses; her eyes said this was no big deal but her inner self said that something was out of the ordinary.
1453122121.title: Maki's Secret Hoard

14531221212.content:
"I can't say how," Maki told them, "But last week I had acquired a most unusual machine." She walked over to an alcove containing something that looked like a cross between a train ticket machine, a dance pad and something out of an American sci-fi. "This can tap into a whole array of parallel universes, if you understand what they are." All of them nodded, knowing the basic idea of parallel dimensions. "It can home in on anything from one person to a whole metropolis," She continued, "And bring it here, except that it is much smaller in order to maintain a balance; as such the people are no bigger than ants." Once again there were mixed reactions. Rika and Chiharu felt that this was some kind of late April Fool while Tomoyo was intrigued, Sakura felt ambivelent between concern and intrigue, and Naoko was thrilled that something genuinely out of the ordinary was here. "So the balance is maintained the equivelent amount of material is sent back to replace it; usually bits of asteroids being implanted in the surface of an alternative Earth to fill the gap that taking such has left behind. Of course only houses or bigger are pre-packed in these boxes," She gestured to the containers around the room, "So they won't spend hours on end staring up at giants like us. Instead they'll think that they're cut off from the rest of their world in more mundane ways. If the box is opened the illusion will be shattered." Sakura now felt rather uneasy at the prospect of being seen as a giant again but there seemed to be something that didn't make it so bad.

How do the others react?
14531221212.title: Trans-Dimensional Toys?

145312212121.content:
"Does this mean...?" Naoko asked with great anticipation.

"Indeed, Yanagisawa-san." Maki replied. "You are the select few who can buy these. I may allow for more potential buyers but currently only you can purchase."

"But," Rika commented, "These are real people! You can't just band them about like toys." Maki sighed in a way that suggested she expected this argument.

"Sasaki-san," She explained, "There are so many dimensions that there's the option that being at your mercy could be better than if they weren't brought here. There'll still be many other versions of these people carrying on as if nothing happened; as such you could each have the same town that has had the same history." Rika calmed down a bit; Sakura was thankful that it had been explained.

"Matsumoto-san," Chiharu asked, pushing the issue further, "Have you tried looking at it from their point of view?" Maki nodded.

"I tried to think about what it would be like to step outside one day only to see my own face filling the sky; it always ended happily." With that explaination it now dawned on all of them that they could buy Tomoeda and actually hold themselves in between their fingers. That made them feel shaky but it sort of improved the issue.

Who is next to speak?
145312212121.title: Concerns and Possibilities

1453122121212.content:
"Um," Tomoyo mused, "How much were you thinking of charging us for them, Matsumoto-san?" Matsumoto now put her business cap on and starting to process the prices.

"Well," She commenced, "This machine is surprisingly energy efficient so the electricity bill doesn't have much impact. I'd say it depends as to whether you want them 'off the shelf', as it were, or you'd like to make a custom order." Tomoyo understood what she meant clearly but business jargon was lost on the others. "First let's talk 'off the shelf' purchases:

Individual People: 2¥ each.

Vehicles: 3¥ per motorbike, 5¥ per car, 7¥ per van or minibus, 10¥ per lorry or single-decker bus, 12¥ per double-decker bus or coach; the number of occupants does not influence the price.

Other Transports: 10¥ per train (regardless of quality or quantity), 5¥-80¥ per boat/ship (depending on size), 8¥-50¥ per plane (depending on size); ditto with regards to occupants.

Houses: 20¥-180¥ (depending on size and quality); ditto.

Neighbourhoods and City Blocks: 100¥ each.

Villages: 200¥ each.

Towns: 500¥ each.

Cities: 1,000¥ each.

Metropolii: 5,000¥ each.

"But if you want any people or places in particular," Matsumoto continued, "Then the prices will be..."
1453122121212.title: The Price List

14531221212121.content:
Upon hearing this is was noted that, considering what they would get, all agreed that she was practically giving them away. Naoko checked something with Maki.

"You mean for twice the normal price we could have anyone, anywhere?" She asked.

"Absolutely." Maki responded. "And you can even have them from particular times, seeing as how they're from other dimensions."

"Amazing!" Naoko, Chiharu and Tomoyo remarked. Sakura had been mulling this over and came round to the fact that it could be done, seeing as how there'd still be dimensions where intervention had not occurred, allowing all five of them to have the exact same place with the exact same circumstances. Suddenly she remembered one thing that Maki had mentioned.

"Matsumoto-san," Said Sakura, "You said only houses or above were in these boxes, so they don't realise what's happened... yet."

"That's right, Kinomoto-san." Maki answered.

"So," Sakura continued, "What about the others?" Getting the drift Maki told her.
14531221212121.title: Inquiries Continue

145312212121212.content: As it turned out, those in forms of transport and/or those on foot were in the situation of...
145312212121212.title: Hotel Little?

choices: The device also dissolves language barriers
1453122121212121.content:
"I keep them in a sort-of hotel." Matsumoto replied. "Of course their reactions are very intense but the passage of time helps." Tomoyo and Naoko understood this the most. "Because they're so small," Maki continued, "It's very easy to see that their needs are met." Rika and Chiharu gave her a very clear look of bewilderment. "I currently have 1,730 individuals residing there and, together, they use about the same amount of resources in one day as I do, so it's just like having one person living with me." She smiled in such a way to indicate reassurance and happiness.

"One thing." Sakura inquired. "Some of them won't be able to understand Japanese. I mean they're from many different countries and times, right?" Matsumoto's smile didn't falter. Why?
1453122121212121.title: Multi-National Tinies

14531221212121212.content: It so happened that the language issue didn't matter because...
14531221212121212.title: Universal Translator?

145312212121212121.content:
"When they all materialise in this world," Maki explained, "Microscopic implants that even they won't notice occur, allowing them to communicate freely, even with us." This now caught Naoko's attention as she was still thinking about the prospect.

"Does that mean their voices are amplified?" She asked.

"Not quite." Maki answered. "Only the language barrier is worked around, not the issue of volume to size, although our voices may appear quieter than they'd expect."

With all of this settled all the girls now gathered round to discuss whether or not to go along with this. Sakura was the one who had the most issues but, after a thorough discussion, she finally decided to go along with it, reminding herself that there'd still be other versions of the little ones.

Later on Matsumoto gave them leave to browse the merchandise while she waited in an annex of the room where the 'hotel' was, so as to help calm her tenants down if and when a customer were to take in interest in buying any of them. She pointed out that all which were pre-packed had a serial number. These were to be used as reference for the punter as, due to the delicate nature of the stock, it typically had to be teleported to the buyer.

Who to follow?

14531221212121212112.content: Shall we follow Tomoyo Daidouji's story of shopping for tiny people?
